content.description:
Two small objects of mass <math alttext="m sub 0" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and a rotating platform of radius <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and rotational inertia <math alttext="I sub p" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> about its center compose a single system. Students use the system to conduct two experiments. The objects are assumed to be point masses.

Experiment 1

Each object of mass <math alttext="m sub 0" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is placed a distance <math alttext="r sub 1" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> away from the center of the platform such that both masses are on opposite sides of the platform. A constant tangential force <math alttext="F sub 0" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is applied to the edge of the platform for a time <math alttext="delta t sub 0" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown in Figure 1. The system is initially at rest.

Experiment 2

Each object of mass <math alttext="m sub 0" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is placed a distance <math alttext="r sub 2" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> away from the center of the platform such that both masses are on opposite sides of the platform. Distance <math alttext="r sub 2 is less than r sub 1" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> . A constant tangential force <math alttext="F sub 0" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is applied to the edge of the platform for a time <math alttext="delta t sub 0" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> , as shown in Figure 2. The system is initially at rest.
content.question: Consider both experiments in Figure 1 and Figure 2. How do the angular momentum of each system, <math alttext="L sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="L sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the angular speed of each system, <math alttext="omega sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="omega sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, compare after a time <math alttext="delta t sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

choices.label: <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="omega " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="L sub 1 equals L sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="omega sub 1 is greater than omega sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="omega " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="L sub 1 equals L sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="omega sub 1 is less than omega sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="omega " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="L sub 1 is less than L sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="omega sub 1 is greater than omega sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="omega " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="L sub 1 is less than L sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="omega sub 1 is less than omega sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="omega " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="L sub 1 equals L sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="omega sub 1 is less than omega sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>

unit.text: 6: Energy and Momentum of Rotating Systems

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
